\DoxyCodeLine{103 \textcolor{comment}{** \string^(The [SQLITE\_VERSION\_NUMBER] C preprocessor macro resolves to an integer}}
\DoxyCodeLine{104 \textcolor{comment}{** with the value (X*1000000 + Y*1000 + Z) where X, Y, and Z are the same}}

\DoxyCodeLine{106 \textcolor{comment}{** The SQLITE\_VERSION\_NUMBER for any given release of SQLite will also}}
\DoxyCodeLine{107 \textcolor{comment}{** be larger than the release from which it is derived.  Either Y will}}
\DoxyCodeLine{108 \textcolor{comment}{** be held constant and Z will be incremented or else Y will be incremented}}

\DoxyCodeLine{110 \textcolor{comment}{**}}

\DoxyCodeLine{197 \textcolor{comment}{/*}}
\DoxyCodeLine{198 \textcolor{comment}{** CAPI3REF: Test To See If The Library Is Threadsafe}}
\DoxyCodeLine{199 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{200 \textcolor{comment}{** \string^The sqlite3\_threadsafe() function returns zero if and only if}}
\DoxyCodeLine{201 \textcolor{comment}{** SQLite was compiled with mutexing code omitted due to the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{202 \textcolor{comment}{** [SQLITE\_THREADSAFE] compile-\/time option being set to 0.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{203 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{204 \textcolor{comment}{** SQLite can be compiled with or without mutexes.  When}}
\DoxyCodeLine{205 \textcolor{comment}{** the [SQLITE\_THREADSAFE] C preprocessor macro is 1 or 2, mutexes}}
\DoxyCodeLine{206 \textcolor{comment}{** are enabled and SQLite is threadsafe.  When the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{207 \textcolor{comment}{** [SQLITE\_THREADSAFE] macro is 0,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{208 \textcolor{comment}{** the mutexes are omitted.  Without the mutexes, it is not safe}}
\DoxyCodeLine{209 \textcolor{comment}{** to use SQLite concurrently from more than one thread.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{210 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{211 \textcolor{comment}{** Enabling mutexes incurs a measurable performance penalty.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{212 \textcolor{comment}{** So if speed is of utmost importance, it makes sense to disable}}
\DoxyCodeLine{213 \textcolor{comment}{** the mutexes.  But for maximum safety, mutexes should be enabled.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{214 \textcolor{comment}{** \string^The default behavior is for mutexes to be enabled.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{215 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{216 \textcolor{comment}{** This interface can be used by an application to make sure that the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{217 \textcolor{comment}{** version of SQLite that it is linking against was compiled with}}
\DoxyCodeLine{218 \textcolor{comment}{** the desired setting of the [SQLITE\_THREADSAFE] macro.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{219 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{220 \textcolor{comment}{** This interface only reports on the compile-\/time mutex setting}}
\DoxyCodeLine{221 \textcolor{comment}{** of the [SQLITE\_THREADSAFE] flag.  If SQLite is compiled with}}

\DoxyCodeLine{223 \textcolor{comment}{** can be fully or partially disabled using a call to [sqlite3\_config()]}}

\DoxyCodeLine{231 \textcolor{comment}{** See the [threading mode] documentation for additional information.}}

\DoxyCodeLine{2288 \textcolor{comment}{** <dd>The SQLITE\_DBCONFIG\_TRUSTED\_SCHEMA option tells SQLite to}}

\DoxyCodeLine{2292 \textcolor{comment}{** including:}}

\DoxyCodeLine{2299 \textcolor{comment}{** unless those virtual tables are tagged with [SQLITE\_VTAB\_INNOCUOUS].}}
\DoxyCodeLine{2300 \textcolor{comment}{** </ul>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{2301 \textcolor{comment}{** This setting defaults to "{}on"{} for legacy compatibility, however}}

\DoxyCodeLine{3542 \textcolor{comment}{** These are utility routines, useful to [VFS|custom VFS implementations],}}

\DoxyCodeLine{3565 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3566 \textcolor{comment}{** The sqlite3\_uri\_boolean(F,P,B) routine assumes that P is a boolean}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3567 \textcolor{comment}{** parameter and returns true (1) or false (0) according to the value}}

\DoxyCodeLine{7748 \textcolor{comment}{** <ul>}}

\DoxyCodeLine{7756 \textcolor{comment}{** <li> Include a digit somewhere in every identifier name.}}

\DoxyCodeLine{10198 \textcolor{comment}{** <h3>Changeset Generation</h3>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10199 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10200 \textcolor{comment}{** Once a table has been attached to a session object, the session object}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10201 \textcolor{comment}{** records the primary key values of all new rows inserted into the table.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10202 \textcolor{comment}{** It also records the original primary key and other column values of any}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10203 \textcolor{comment}{** deleted or updated rows. For each unique primary key value, data is only}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10204 \textcolor{comment}{** recorded once -\/ the first time a row with said primary key is inserted,}}

\DoxyCodeLine{10206 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10207 \textcolor{comment}{** There is one exception to the previous paragraph: when a row is inserted,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10208 \textcolor{comment}{** updated or deleted, if one or more of its primary key columns contain a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10209 \textcolor{comment}{** NULL value, no record of the change is made.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10210 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10211 \textcolor{comment}{** The session object therefore accumulates two types of records -\/ those}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10212 \textcolor{comment}{** that consist of primary key values only (created when the user inserts}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10213 \textcolor{comment}{** a new record) and those that consist of the primary key values and the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10214 \textcolor{comment}{** original values of other table columns (created when the users deletes}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10215 \textcolor{comment}{** or updates a record).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10216 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10217 \textcolor{comment}{** When this function is called, the requested changeset is created using}}

\DoxyCodeLine{10220 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10221 \textcolor{comment}{** <ul>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10222 \textcolor{comment}{**   <li> For each record generated by an insert, the database is queried}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10223 \textcolor{comment}{**        for a row with a matching primary key. If one is found, an INSERT}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10224 \textcolor{comment}{**        change is added to the changeset. If no such row is found, no change}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10225 \textcolor{comment}{**        is added to the changeset.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10226 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10227 \textcolor{comment}{**   <li> For each record generated by an update or delete, the database is}}

\DoxyCodeLine{10229 \textcolor{comment}{**        found and one or more of the non-\/primary key fields have been}}

\DoxyCodeLine{11124 \textcolor{comment}{/*}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11125 \textcolor{comment}{** CAPI3REF: Constants Passed To The Conflict Handler}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11126 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11127 \textcolor{comment}{** Values that may be passed as the second argument to a conflict-\/handler.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11128 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11129 \textcolor{comment}{** <dl>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11130 \textcolor{comment}{** <dt>SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_DATA<dd>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11131 \textcolor{comment}{**   The conflict handler is invoked with CHANGESET\_DATA as the second argument}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11132 \textcolor{comment}{**   when processing a DELETE or UPDATE change if a row with the required}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11133 \textcolor{comment}{**   PRIMARY KEY fields is present in the database, but one or more other}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11134 \textcolor{comment}{**   (non primary-\/key) fields modified by the update do not contain the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11135 \textcolor{comment}{**   expected "{}before"{} values.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11136 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11137 \textcolor{comment}{**   The conflicting row, in this case, is the database row with the matching}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11138 \textcolor{comment}{**   primary key.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11139 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11140 \textcolor{comment}{** <dt>SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_NOTFOUND<dd>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11141 \textcolor{comment}{**   The conflict handler is invoked with CHANGESET\_NOTFOUND as the second}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11142 \textcolor{comment}{**   argument when processing a DELETE or UPDATE change if a row with the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11143 \textcolor{comment}{**   required PRIMARY KEY fields is not present in the database.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11144 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11145 \textcolor{comment}{**   There is no conflicting row in this case. The results of invoking the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11146 \textcolor{comment}{**   sqlite3changeset\_conflict() API are undefined.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11147 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11148 \textcolor{comment}{** <dt>SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_CONFLICT<dd>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11149 \textcolor{comment}{**   CHANGESET\_CONFLICT is passed as the second argument to the conflict}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11150 \textcolor{comment}{**   handler while processing an INSERT change if the operation would result}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11151 \textcolor{comment}{**   in duplicate primary key values.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11152 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11153 \textcolor{comment}{**   The conflicting row in this case is the database row with the matching}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11154 \textcolor{comment}{**   primary key.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11155 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11156 \textcolor{comment}{** <dt>SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_FOREIGN\_KEY<dd>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11157 \textcolor{comment}{**   If foreign key handling is enabled, and applying a changeset leaves the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11158 \textcolor{comment}{**   database in a state containing foreign key violations, the conflict}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11159 \textcolor{comment}{**   handler is invoked with CHANGESET\_FOREIGN\_KEY as the second argument}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11160 \textcolor{comment}{**   exactly once before the changeset is committed. If the conflict handler}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11161 \textcolor{comment}{**   returns CHANGESET\_OMIT, the changes, including those that caused the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11162 \textcolor{comment}{**   foreign key constraint violation, are committed. Or, if it returns}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11163 \textcolor{comment}{**   CHANGESET\_ABORT, the changeset is rolled back.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11164 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11165 \textcolor{comment}{**   No current or conflicting row information is provided. The only function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11166 \textcolor{comment}{**   it is possible to call on the supplied sqlite3\_changeset\_iter handle}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11167 \textcolor{comment}{**   is sqlite3changeset\_fk\_conflicts().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11168 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11169 \textcolor{comment}{** <dt>SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_CONSTRAINT<dd>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11170 \textcolor{comment}{**   If any other constraint violation occurs while applying a change (i.e.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11171 \textcolor{comment}{**   a UNIQUE, CHECK or NOT NULL constraint), the conflict handler is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11172 \textcolor{comment}{**   invoked with CHANGESET\_CONSTRAINT as the second argument.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11173 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11174 \textcolor{comment}{**   There is no conflicting row in this case. The results of invoking the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11175 \textcolor{comment}{**   sqlite3changeset\_conflict() API are undefined.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11176 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11177 \textcolor{comment}{** </dl>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11178 \textcolor{comment}{*/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11179 \textcolor{preprocessor}{\#define SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_DATA        1}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11180 \textcolor{preprocessor}{\#define SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_NOTFOUND    2}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11181 \textcolor{preprocessor}{\#define SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_CONFLICT    3}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11182 \textcolor{preprocessor}{\#define SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_CONSTRAINT  4}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11183 \textcolor{preprocessor}{\#define SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_FOREIGN\_KEY 5}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11184 }
\DoxyCodeLine{11185 \textcolor{comment}{/*}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11186 \textcolor{comment}{** CAPI3REF: Constants Returned By The Conflict Handler}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11187 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11188 \textcolor{comment}{** A conflict handler callback must return one of the following three values.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11189 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11190 \textcolor{comment}{** <dl>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11191 \textcolor{comment}{** <dt>SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_OMIT<dd>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11192 \textcolor{comment}{**   If a conflict handler returns this value no special action is taken. The}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11193 \textcolor{comment}{**   change that caused the conflict is not applied. The session module}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11194 \textcolor{comment}{**   continues to the next change in the changeset.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11195 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11196 \textcolor{comment}{** <dt>SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_REPLACE<dd>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11197 \textcolor{comment}{**   This value may only be returned if the second argument to the conflict}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11198 \textcolor{comment}{**   handler was SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_DATA or SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_CONFLICT. If this}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11199 \textcolor{comment}{**   is not the case, any changes applied so far are rolled back and the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11200 \textcolor{comment}{**   call to sqlite3changeset\_apply() returns SQLITE\_MISUSE.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11201 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11202 \textcolor{comment}{**   If CHANGESET\_REPLACE is returned by an SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_DATA conflict}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11203 \textcolor{comment}{**   handler, then the conflicting row is either updated or deleted, depending}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11204 \textcolor{comment}{**   on the type of change.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11205 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11206 \textcolor{comment}{**   If CHANGESET\_REPLACE is returned by an SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_CONFLICT conflict}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11207 \textcolor{comment}{**   handler, then the conflicting row is removed from the database and a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11208 \textcolor{comment}{**   second attempt to apply the change is made. If this second attempt fails,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11209 \textcolor{comment}{**   the original row is restored to the database before continuing.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11210 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11211 \textcolor{comment}{** <dt>SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_ABORT<dd>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11212 \textcolor{comment}{**   If this value is returned, any changes applied so far are rolled back}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11213 \textcolor{comment}{**   and the call to sqlite3changeset\_apply() returns SQLITE\_ABORT.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11214 \textcolor{comment}{** </dl>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11215 \textcolor{comment}{*/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11216 \textcolor{preprocessor}{\#define SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_OMIT       0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11217 \textcolor{preprocessor}{\#define SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_REPLACE    1}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11218 \textcolor{preprocessor}{\#define SQLITE\_CHANGESET\_ABORT      2}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11219 }
\DoxyCodeLine{11220 \textcolor{comment}{/*}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11221 \textcolor{comment}{** CAPI3REF: Rebasing changesets}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11222 \textcolor{comment}{** EXPERIMENTAL}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11223 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11224 \textcolor{comment}{** Suppose there is a site hosting a database in state S0. And that}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11225 \textcolor{comment}{** modifications are made that move that database to state S1 and a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11226 \textcolor{comment}{** changeset recorded (the "{}local"{} changeset). Then, a changeset based}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11227 \textcolor{comment}{** on S0 is received from another site (the "{}remote"{} changeset) and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11228 \textcolor{comment}{** applied to the database. The database is then in state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11229 \textcolor{comment}{** (S1+"{}remote"{}), where the exact state depends on any conflict}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11230 \textcolor{comment}{** resolution decisions (OMIT or REPLACE) made while applying "{}remote"{}.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11231 \textcolor{comment}{** Rebasing a changeset is to update it to take those conflict}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11232 \textcolor{comment}{** resolution decisions into account, so that the same conflicts}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11233 \textcolor{comment}{** do not have to be resolved elsewhere in the network.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11234 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11235 \textcolor{comment}{** For example, if both the local and remote changesets contain an}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11236 \textcolor{comment}{** INSERT of the same key on "{}CREATE TABLE t1(a PRIMARY KEY, b)"{}:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11237 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11238 \textcolor{comment}{**   local:  INSERT INTO t1 VALUES(1, 'v1');}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11239 \textcolor{comment}{**   remote: INSERT INTO t1 VALUES(1, 'v2');}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11240 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11241 \textcolor{comment}{** and the conflict resolution is REPLACE, then the INSERT change is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11242 \textcolor{comment}{** removed from the local changeset (it was overridden). Or, if the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11243 \textcolor{comment}{** conflict resolution was "{}OMIT"{}, then the local changeset is modified}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11244 \textcolor{comment}{** to instead contain:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11245 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11246 \textcolor{comment}{**           UPDATE t1 SET b = 'v2' WHERE a=1;}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11247 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11248 \textcolor{comment}{** Changes within the local changeset are rebased as follows:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11249 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11250 \textcolor{comment}{** <dl>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11251 \textcolor{comment}{** <dt>Local INSERT<dd>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11252 \textcolor{comment}{**   This may only conflict with a remote INSERT. If the conflict}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11253 \textcolor{comment}{**   resolution was OMIT, then add an UPDATE change to the rebased}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11254 \textcolor{comment}{**   changeset. Or, if the conflict resolution was REPLACE, add}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11255 \textcolor{comment}{**   nothing to the rebased changeset.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11256 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11257 \textcolor{comment}{** <dt>Local DELETE<dd>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11258 \textcolor{comment}{**   This may conflict with a remote UPDATE or DELETE. In both cases the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11259 \textcolor{comment}{**   only possible resolution is OMIT. If the remote operation was a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11260 \textcolor{comment}{**   DELETE, then add no change to the rebased changeset. If the remote}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11261 \textcolor{comment}{**   operation was an UPDATE, then the old.* fields of change are updated}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11262 \textcolor{comment}{**   to reflect the new.* values in the UPDATE.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11263 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11264 \textcolor{comment}{** <dt>Local UPDATE<dd>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11265 \textcolor{comment}{**   This may conflict with a remote UPDATE or DELETE. If it conflicts}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11266 \textcolor{comment}{**   with a DELETE, and the conflict resolution was OMIT, then the update}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11267 \textcolor{comment}{**   is changed into an INSERT. Any undefined values in the new.* record}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11268 \textcolor{comment}{**   from the update change are filled in using the old.* values from}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11269 \textcolor{comment}{**   the conflicting DELETE. Or, if the conflict resolution was REPLACE,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11270 \textcolor{comment}{**   the UPDATE change is simply omitted from the rebased changeset.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11271 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11272 \textcolor{comment}{**   If conflict is with a remote UPDATE and the resolution is OMIT, then}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11273 \textcolor{comment}{**   the old.* values are rebased using the new.* values in the remote}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11274 \textcolor{comment}{**   change. Or, if the resolution is REPLACE, then the change is copied}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11275 \textcolor{comment}{**   into the rebased changeset with updates to columns also updated by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11276 \textcolor{comment}{**   the conflicting remote UPDATE removed. If this means no columns would}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11277 \textcolor{comment}{**   be updated, the change is omitted.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11278 \textcolor{comment}{** </dl>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11279 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11280 \textcolor{comment}{** A local change may be rebased against multiple remote changes}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11281 \textcolor{comment}{** simultaneously. If a single key is modified by multiple remote}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11282 \textcolor{comment}{** changesets, they are combined as follows before the local changeset}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11283 \textcolor{comment}{** is rebased:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11284 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11285 \textcolor{comment}{** <ul>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11286 \textcolor{comment}{**    <li> If there has been one or more REPLACE resolutions on a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11287 \textcolor{comment}{**         key, it is rebased according to a REPLACE.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11288 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11289 \textcolor{comment}{**    <li> If there have been no REPLACE resolutions on a key, then}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11290 \textcolor{comment}{**         the local changeset is rebased according to the most recent}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11291 \textcolor{comment}{**         of the OMIT resolutions.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11292 \textcolor{comment}{** </ul>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11293 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11294 \textcolor{comment}{** Note that conflict resolutions from multiple remote changesets are}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11295 \textcolor{comment}{** combined on a per-\/field basis, not per-\/row. This means that in the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11296 \textcolor{comment}{** case of multiple remote UPDATE operations, some fields of a single}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11297 \textcolor{comment}{** local change may be rebased for REPLACE while others are rebased for}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11298 \textcolor{comment}{** OMIT.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11299 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11300 \textcolor{comment}{** In order to rebase a local changeset, the remote changeset must first}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11301 \textcolor{comment}{** be applied to the local database using sqlite3changeset\_apply\_v2() and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11302 \textcolor{comment}{** the buffer of rebase information captured. Then:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11303 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11304 \textcolor{comment}{** <ol>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11305 \textcolor{comment}{**   <li> An sqlite3\_rebaser object is created by calling}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11306 \textcolor{comment}{**        sqlite3rebaser\_create().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11307 \textcolor{comment}{**   <li> The new object is configured with the rebase buffer obtained from}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11308 \textcolor{comment}{**        sqlite3changeset\_apply\_v2() by calling sqlite3rebaser\_configure().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11309 \textcolor{comment}{**        If the local changeset is to be rebased against multiple remote}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11310 \textcolor{comment}{**        changesets, then sqlite3rebaser\_configure() should be called}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11311 \textcolor{comment}{**        multiple times, in the same order that the multiple}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11312 \textcolor{comment}{**        sqlite3changeset\_apply\_v2() calls were made.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11313 \textcolor{comment}{**   <li> Each local changeset is rebased by calling sqlite3rebaser\_rebase().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11314 \textcolor{comment}{**   <li> The sqlite3\_rebaser object is deleted by calling}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11315 \textcolor{comment}{**        sqlite3rebaser\_delete().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11316 \textcolor{comment}{** </ol>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11317 \textcolor{comment}{*/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11318 \textcolor{keyword}{typedef} \textcolor{keyword}{struct }sqlite3\_rebaser sqlite3\_rebaser;}
\DoxyCodeLine{11319 }
\DoxyCodeLine{11320 \textcolor{comment}{/*}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11321 \textcolor{comment}{** CAPI3REF: Create a changeset rebaser object.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11322 \textcolor{comment}{** EXPERIMENTAL}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11323 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11324 \textcolor{comment}{** Allocate a new changeset rebaser object. If successful, set (*ppNew) to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11325 \textcolor{comment}{** point to the new object and return SQLITE\_OK. Otherwise, if an error}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11326 \textcolor{comment}{** occurs, return an SQLite error code (e.g. SQLITE\_NOMEM) and set (*ppNew)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11327 \textcolor{comment}{** to NULL.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11328 \textcolor{comment}{*/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11329 SQLITE\_API \textcolor{keywordtype}{int} sqlite3rebaser\_create(sqlite3\_rebaser **ppNew);}
\DoxyCodeLine{11330 }
\DoxyCodeLine{11331 \textcolor{comment}{/*}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11332 \textcolor{comment}{** CAPI3REF: Configure a changeset rebaser object.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11333 \textcolor{comment}{** EXPERIMENTAL}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11334 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11335 \textcolor{comment}{** Configure the changeset rebaser object to rebase changesets according}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11336 \textcolor{comment}{** to the conflict resolutions described by buffer pRebase (size nRebase}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11337 \textcolor{comment}{** bytes), which must have been obtained from a previous call to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11338 \textcolor{comment}{** sqlite3changeset\_apply\_v2().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11339 \textcolor{comment}{*/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11340 SQLITE\_API \textcolor{keywordtype}{int} sqlite3rebaser\_configure(}
\DoxyCodeLine{11341   sqlite3\_rebaser*,}
\DoxyCodeLine{11342   \textcolor{keywordtype}{int} nRebase, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \textcolor{keywordtype}{void} *pRebase}
\DoxyCodeLine{11343 );}
\DoxyCodeLine{11344 }
\DoxyCodeLine{11345 \textcolor{comment}{/*}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11346 \textcolor{comment}{** CAPI3REF: Rebase a changeset}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11347 \textcolor{comment}{** EXPERIMENTAL}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11348 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11349 \textcolor{comment}{** Argument pIn must point to a buffer containing a changeset nIn bytes}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11350 \textcolor{comment}{** in size. This function allocates and populates a buffer with a copy}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11351 \textcolor{comment}{** of the changeset rebased according to the configuration of the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11352 \textcolor{comment}{** rebaser object passed as the first argument. If successful, (*ppOut)}}

\DoxyCodeLine{11377 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11378 \textcolor{comment}{** The six streaming API xxx\_strm() functions serve similar purposes to the}}

\DoxyCodeLine{11380 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11381 \textcolor{comment}{** <table border=1 style="{}margin-\/left:8ex;margin-\/right:8ex"{}>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11382 \textcolor{comment}{**   <tr><th>Streaming function<th>Non-\/streaming equivalent</th>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11383 \textcolor{comment}{**   <tr><td>sqlite3changeset\_apply\_strm<td>[sqlite3changeset\_apply]}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11384 \textcolor{comment}{**   <tr><td>sqlite3changeset\_apply\_strm\_v2<td>[sqlite3changeset\_apply\_v2]}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11385 \textcolor{comment}{**   <tr><td>sqlite3changeset\_concat\_strm<td>[sqlite3changeset\_concat]}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11386 \textcolor{comment}{**   <tr><td>sqlite3changeset\_invert\_strm<td>[sqlite3changeset\_invert]}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11387 \textcolor{comment}{**   <tr><td>sqlite3changeset\_start\_strm<td>[sqlite3changeset\_start]}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11388 \textcolor{comment}{**   <tr><td>sqlite3session\_changeset\_strm<td>[sqlite3session\_changeset]}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11389 \textcolor{comment}{**   <tr><td>sqlite3session\_patchset\_strm<td>[sqlite3session\_patchset]}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11390 \textcolor{comment}{** </table>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11391 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11392 \textcolor{comment}{** Non-\/streaming functions that accept changesets (or patchsets) as input}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11393 \textcolor{comment}{** require that the entire changeset be stored in a single buffer in memory.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11394 \textcolor{comment}{** Similarly, those that return a changeset or patchset do so by returning}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11395 \textcolor{comment}{** a pointer to a single large buffer allocated using sqlite3\_malloc().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11396 \textcolor{comment}{** Normally this is convenient. However, if an application running in a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11397 \textcolor{comment}{** low-\/memory environment is required to handle very large changesets, the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11398 \textcolor{comment}{** large contiguous memory allocations required can become onerous.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11399 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11400 \textcolor{comment}{** In order to avoid this problem, instead of a single large buffer, input}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11401 \textcolor{comment}{** is passed to a streaming API functions by way of a callback function that}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11402 \textcolor{comment}{** the sessions module invokes to incrementally request input data as it is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11403 \textcolor{comment}{** required. In all cases, a pair of API function parameters such as}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11404 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11405 \textcolor{comment}{**  <pre>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11406 \textcolor{comment}{**  \&nbsp;     int nChangeset,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11407 \textcolor{comment}{**  \&nbsp;     void *pChangeset,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11408 \textcolor{comment}{**  </pre>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11409 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11410 \textcolor{comment}{** Is replaced by:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11411 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11412 \textcolor{comment}{**  <pre>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11413 \textcolor{comment}{**  \&nbsp;     int (*xInput)(void *pIn, void *pData, int *pnData),}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11414 \textcolor{comment}{**  \&nbsp;     void *pIn,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11415 \textcolor{comment}{**  </pre>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11416 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11417 \textcolor{comment}{** Each time the xInput callback is invoked by the sessions module, the first}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11418 \textcolor{comment}{** argument passed is a copy of the supplied pIn context pointer. The second}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11419 \textcolor{comment}{** argument, pData, points to a buffer (*pnData) bytes in size. Assuming no}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11420 \textcolor{comment}{** error occurs the xInput method should copy up to (*pnData) bytes of data}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11421 \textcolor{comment}{** into the buffer and set (*pnData) to the actual number of bytes copied}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11422 \textcolor{comment}{** before returning SQLITE\_OK. If the input is completely exhausted, (*pnData)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11423 \textcolor{comment}{** should be set to zero to indicate this. Or, if an error occurs, an SQLite}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11424 \textcolor{comment}{** error code should be returned. In all cases, if an xInput callback returns}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11425 \textcolor{comment}{** an error, all processing is abandoned and the streaming API function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11426 \textcolor{comment}{** returns a copy of the error code to the caller.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11427 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11428 \textcolor{comment}{** In the case of sqlite3changeset\_start\_strm(), the xInput callback may be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11429 \textcolor{comment}{** invoked by the sessions module at any point during the lifetime of the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11430 \textcolor{comment}{** iterator. If such an xInput callback returns an error, the iterator enters}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11431 \textcolor{comment}{** an error state, whereby all subsequent calls to iterator functions}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11432 \textcolor{comment}{** immediately fail with the same error code as returned by xInput.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11433 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11434 \textcolor{comment}{** Similarly, streaming API functions that return changesets (or patchsets)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11435 \textcolor{comment}{** return them in chunks by way of a callback function instead of via a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11436 \textcolor{comment}{** pointer to a single large buffer. In this case, a pair of parameters such}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11437 \textcolor{comment}{** as:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11438 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11439 \textcolor{comment}{**  <pre>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11440 \textcolor{comment}{**  \&nbsp;     int *pnChangeset,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11441 \textcolor{comment}{**  \&nbsp;     void **ppChangeset,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11442 \textcolor{comment}{**  </pre>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11443 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11444 \textcolor{comment}{** Is replaced by:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11445 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11446 \textcolor{comment}{**  <pre>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11447 \textcolor{comment}{**  \&nbsp;     int (*xOutput)(void *pOut, const void *pData, int nData),}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11448 \textcolor{comment}{**  \&nbsp;     void *pOut}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11449 \textcolor{comment}{**  </pre>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11450 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11451 \textcolor{comment}{** The xOutput callback is invoked zero or more times to return data to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11452 \textcolor{comment}{** the application. The first parameter passed to each call is a copy of the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11453 \textcolor{comment}{** pOut pointer supplied by the application. The second parameter, pData,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11454 \textcolor{comment}{** points to a buffer nData bytes in size containing the chunk of output}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11455 \textcolor{comment}{** data being returned. If the xOutput callback successfully processes the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11456 \textcolor{comment}{** supplied data, it should return SQLITE\_OK to indicate success. Otherwise,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11457 \textcolor{comment}{** it should return some other SQLite error code. In this case processing}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11458 \textcolor{comment}{** is immediately abandoned and the streaming API function returns a copy}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11459 \textcolor{comment}{** of the xOutput error code to the application.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11460 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11461 \textcolor{comment}{** The sessions module never invokes an xOutput callback with the third}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11462 \textcolor{comment}{** parameter set to a value less than or equal to zero. Other than this,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11463 \textcolor{comment}{** no guarantees are made as to the size of the chunks of data returned.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11464 \textcolor{comment}{*/}}

\DoxyCodeLine{11907 \textcolor{comment}{** Applications may also register custom tokenizer types. A tokenizer}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11908 \textcolor{comment}{** is registered by providing fts5 with a populated instance of the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11909 \textcolor{comment}{** following structure. All structure methods must be defined, setting}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11910 \textcolor{comment}{** any member of the fts5\_tokenizer struct to NULL leads to undefined}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11911 \textcolor{comment}{** behaviour. The structure methods are expected to function as follows:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11912 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11913 \textcolor{comment}{** xCreate:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11914 \textcolor{comment}{**   This function is used to allocate and initialize a tokenizer instance.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11915 \textcolor{comment}{**   A tokenizer instance is required to actually tokenize text.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11916 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11917 \textcolor{comment}{**   The first argument passed to this function is a copy of the (void*)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11918 \textcolor{comment}{**   pointer provided by the application when the fts5\_tokenizer object}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11919 \textcolor{comment}{**   was registered with FTS5 (the third argument to xCreateTokenizer()).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11920 \textcolor{comment}{**   The second and third arguments are an array of nul-\/terminated strings}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11921 \textcolor{comment}{**   containing the tokenizer arguments, if any, specified following the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11922 \textcolor{comment}{**   tokenizer name as part of the CREATE VIRTUAL TABLE statement used}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11923 \textcolor{comment}{**   to create the FTS5 table.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11924 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11925 \textcolor{comment}{**   The final argument is an output variable. If successful, (*ppOut)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11926 \textcolor{comment}{**   should be set to point to the new tokenizer handle and SQLITE\_OK}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11927 \textcolor{comment}{**   returned. If an error occurs, some value other than SQLITE\_OK should}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11928 \textcolor{comment}{**   be returned. In this case, fts5 assumes that the final value of *ppOut}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11929 \textcolor{comment}{**   is undefined.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11930 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11931 \textcolor{comment}{** xDelete:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11932 \textcolor{comment}{**   This function is invoked to delete a tokenizer handle previously}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11933 \textcolor{comment}{**   allocated using xCreate(). Fts5 guarantees that this function will}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11934 \textcolor{comment}{**   be invoked exactly once for each successful call to xCreate().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11935 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11936 \textcolor{comment}{** xTokenize:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11937 \textcolor{comment}{**   This function is expected to tokenize the nText byte string indicated}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11938 \textcolor{comment}{**   by argument pText. pText may or may not be nul-\/terminated. The first}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11939 \textcolor{comment}{**   argument passed to this function is a pointer to an Fts5Tokenizer object}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11940 \textcolor{comment}{**   returned by an earlier call to xCreate().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11941 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11942 \textcolor{comment}{**   The second argument indicates the reason that FTS5 is requesting}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11943 \textcolor{comment}{**   tokenization of the supplied text. This is always one of the following}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11944 \textcolor{comment}{**   four values:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11945 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11946 \textcolor{comment}{**   <ul><li> <b>FTS5\_TOKENIZE\_DOCUMENT</b> -\/ A document is being inserted into}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11947 \textcolor{comment}{**            or removed from the FTS table. The tokenizer is being invoked to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11948 \textcolor{comment}{**            determine the set of tokens to add to (or delete from) the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11949 \textcolor{comment}{**            FTS index.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11950 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11951 \textcolor{comment}{**       <li> <b>FTS5\_TOKENIZE\_QUERY</b> -\/ A MATCH query is being executed}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11952 \textcolor{comment}{**            against the FTS index. The tokenizer is being called to tokenize}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11953 \textcolor{comment}{**            a bareword or quoted string specified as part of the query.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11954 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11955 \textcolor{comment}{**       <li> <b>(FTS5\_TOKENIZE\_QUERY | FTS5\_TOKENIZE\_PREFIX)</b> -\/ Same as}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11956 \textcolor{comment}{**            FTS5\_TOKENIZE\_QUERY, except that the bareword or quoted string is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11957 \textcolor{comment}{**            followed by a "{}*"{} character, indicating that the last token}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11958 \textcolor{comment}{**            returned by the tokenizer will be treated as a token prefix.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11959 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11960 \textcolor{comment}{**       <li> <b>FTS5\_TOKENIZE\_AUX</b> -\/ The tokenizer is being invoked to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11961 \textcolor{comment}{**            satisfy an fts5\_api.xTokenize() request made by an auxiliary}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11962 \textcolor{comment}{**            function. Or an fts5\_api.xColumnSize() request made by the same}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11963 \textcolor{comment}{**            on a columnsize=0 database.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11964 \textcolor{comment}{**   </ul>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11965 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11966 \textcolor{comment}{**   For each token in the input string, the supplied callback xToken() must}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11967 \textcolor{comment}{**   be invoked. The first argument to it should be a copy of the pointer}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11968 \textcolor{comment}{**   passed as the second argument to xTokenize(). The third and fourth}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11969 \textcolor{comment}{**   arguments are a pointer to a buffer containing the token text, and the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11970 \textcolor{comment}{**   size of the token in bytes. The 4th and 5th arguments are the byte offsets}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11971 \textcolor{comment}{**   of the first byte of and first byte immediately following the text from}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11972 \textcolor{comment}{**   which the token is derived within the input.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11973 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11974 \textcolor{comment}{**   The second argument passed to the xToken() callback ("{}tflags"{}) should}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11975 \textcolor{comment}{**   normally be set to 0. The exception is if the tokenizer supports}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11976 \textcolor{comment}{**   synonyms. In this case see the discussion below for details.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11977 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11978 \textcolor{comment}{**   FTS5 assumes the xToken() callback is invoked for each token in the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11979 \textcolor{comment}{**   order that they occur within the input text.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11980 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11981 \textcolor{comment}{**   If an xToken() callback returns any value other than SQLITE\_OK, then}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11982 \textcolor{comment}{**   the tokenization should be abandoned and the xTokenize() method should}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11983 \textcolor{comment}{**   immediately return a copy of the xToken() return value. Or, if the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11984 \textcolor{comment}{**   input buffer is exhausted, xTokenize() should return SQLITE\_OK. Finally,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11985 \textcolor{comment}{**   if an error occurs with the xTokenize() implementation itself, it}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11986 \textcolor{comment}{**   may abandon the tokenization and return any error code other than}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11987 \textcolor{comment}{**   SQLITE\_OK or SQLITE\_DONE.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11988 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11989 \textcolor{comment}{** SYNONYM SUPPORT}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11990 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11991 \textcolor{comment}{**   Custom tokenizers may also support synonyms. Consider a case in which a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11992 \textcolor{comment}{**   user wishes to query for a phrase such as "{}first place"{}. Using the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11993 \textcolor{comment}{**   built-\/in tokenizers, the FTS5 query 'first + place' will match instances}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11994 \textcolor{comment}{**   of "{}first place"{} within the document set, but not alternative forms}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11995 \textcolor{comment}{**   such as "{}1st place"{}. In some applications, it would be better to match}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11996 \textcolor{comment}{**   all instances of "{}first place"{} or "{}1st place"{} regardless of which form}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11997 \textcolor{comment}{**   the user specified in the MATCH query text.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11998 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11999 \textcolor{comment}{**   There are several ways to approach this in FTS5:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12000 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12001 \textcolor{comment}{**   <ol><li> By mapping all synonyms to a single token. In this case, using}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12002 \textcolor{comment}{**            the above example, this means that the tokenizer returns the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12003 \textcolor{comment}{**            same token for inputs "{}first"{} and "{}1st"{}. Say that token is in}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12004 \textcolor{comment}{**            fact "{}first"{}, so that when the user inserts the document "{}I won}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12005 \textcolor{comment}{**            1st place"{} entries are added to the index for tokens "{}i"{}, "{}won"{},}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12006 \textcolor{comment}{**            "{}first"{} and "{}place"{}. If the user then queries for '1st + place',}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12007 \textcolor{comment}{**            the tokenizer substitutes "{}first"{} for "{}1st"{} and the query works}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12008 \textcolor{comment}{**            as expected.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12009 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12010 \textcolor{comment}{**       <li> By querying the index for all synonyms of each query term}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12011 \textcolor{comment}{**            separately. In this case, when tokenizing query text, the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12012 \textcolor{comment}{**            tokenizer may provide multiple synonyms for a single term}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12013 \textcolor{comment}{**            within the document. FTS5 then queries the index for each}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12014 \textcolor{comment}{**            synonym individually. For example, faced with the query:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12015 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12016 \textcolor{comment}{**   <codeblock>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12017 \textcolor{comment}{**     ... MATCH 'first place'</codeblock>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12018 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12019 \textcolor{comment}{**            the tokenizer offers both "{}1st"{} and "{}first"{} as synonyms for the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12020 \textcolor{comment}{**            first token in the MATCH query and FTS5 effectively runs a query}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12021 \textcolor{comment}{**            similar to:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12022 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12023 \textcolor{comment}{**   <codeblock>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12024 \textcolor{comment}{**     ... MATCH '(first OR 1st) place'</codeblock>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12025 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12026 \textcolor{comment}{**            except that, for the purposes of auxiliary functions, the query}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12027 \textcolor{comment}{**            still appears to contain just two phrases -\/ "{}(first OR 1st)"{}}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12028 \textcolor{comment}{**            being treated as a single phrase.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12029 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12030 \textcolor{comment}{**       <li> By adding multiple synonyms for a single term to the FTS index.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12031 \textcolor{comment}{**            Using this method, when tokenizing document text, the tokenizer}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12032 \textcolor{comment}{**            provides multiple synonyms for each token. So that when a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12033 \textcolor{comment}{**            document such as "{}I won first place"{} is tokenized, entries are}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12034 \textcolor{comment}{**            added to the FTS index for "{}i"{}, "{}won"{}, "{}first"{}, "{}1st"{} and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12035 \textcolor{comment}{**            "{}place"{}.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12036 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12037 \textcolor{comment}{**            This way, even if the tokenizer does not provide synonyms}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12038 \textcolor{comment}{**            when tokenizing query text (it should not -\/ to do so would be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12039 \textcolor{comment}{**            inefficient), it doesn't matter if the user queries for}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12040 \textcolor{comment}{**            'first + place' or '1st + place', as there are entries in the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12041 \textcolor{comment}{**            FTS index corresponding to both forms of the first token.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12042 \textcolor{comment}{**   </ol>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12043 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12044 \textcolor{comment}{**   Whether it is parsing document or query text, any call to xToken that}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12045 \textcolor{comment}{**   specifies a <i>tflags</i> argument with the FTS5\_TOKEN\_COLOCATED bit}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12046 \textcolor{comment}{**   is considered to supply a synonym for the previous token. For example,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12047 \textcolor{comment}{**   when parsing the document "{}I won first place"{}, a tokenizer that supports}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12048 \textcolor{comment}{**   synonyms would call xToken() 5 times, as follows:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12049 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12050 \textcolor{comment}{**   <codeblock>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12051 \textcolor{comment}{**       xToken(pCtx, 0, "{}i"{},                      1,  0,  1);}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12052 \textcolor{comment}{**       xToken(pCtx, 0, "{}won"{},                    3,  2,  5);}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12053 \textcolor{comment}{**       xToken(pCtx, 0, "{}first"{},                  5,  6, 11);}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12054 \textcolor{comment}{**       xToken(pCtx, FTS5\_TOKEN\_COLOCATED, "{}1st"{}, 3,  6, 11);}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12055 \textcolor{comment}{**       xToken(pCtx, 0, "{}place"{},                  5, 12, 17);}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12056 \textcolor{comment}{**</codeblock>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12057 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12058 \textcolor{comment}{**   It is an error to specify the FTS5\_TOKEN\_COLOCATED flag the first time}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12059 \textcolor{comment}{**   xToken() is called. Multiple synonyms may be specified for a single token}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12060 \textcolor{comment}{**   by making multiple calls to xToken(FTS5\_TOKEN\_COLOCATED) in sequence.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12061 \textcolor{comment}{**   There is no limit to the number of synonyms that may be provided for a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12062 \textcolor{comment}{**   single token.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12063 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12064 \textcolor{comment}{**   In many cases, method (1) above is the best approach. It does not add}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12065 \textcolor{comment}{**   extra data to the FTS index or require FTS5 to query for multiple terms,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12066 \textcolor{comment}{**   so it is efficient in terms of disk space and query speed. However, it}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12067 \textcolor{comment}{**   does not support prefix queries very well. If, as suggested above, the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12068 \textcolor{comment}{**   token "{}first"{} is substituted for "{}1st"{} by the tokenizer, then the query:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12069 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12070 \textcolor{comment}{**   <codeblock>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12071 \textcolor{comment}{**     ... MATCH '1s*'</codeblock>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12072 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12073 \textcolor{comment}{**   will not match documents that contain the token "{}1st"{} (as the tokenizer}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12074 \textcolor{comment}{**   will probably not map "{}1s"{} to any prefix of "{}first"{}).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12075 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12076 \textcolor{comment}{**   For full prefix support, method (3) may be preferred. In this case,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12077 \textcolor{comment}{**   because the index contains entries for both "{}first"{} and "{}1st"{}, prefix}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12078 \textcolor{comment}{**   queries such as 'fi*' or '1s*' will match correctly. However, because}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12079 \textcolor{comment}{**   extra entries are added to the FTS index, this method uses more space}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12080 \textcolor{comment}{**   within the database.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12081 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12082 \textcolor{comment}{**   Method (2) offers a midpoint between (1) and (3). Using this method,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12083 \textcolor{comment}{**   a query such as '1s*' will match documents that contain the literal}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12084 \textcolor{comment}{**   token "{}1st"{}, but not "{}first"{} (assuming the tokenizer is not able to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12085 \textcolor{comment}{**   provide synonyms for prefixes). However, a non-\/prefix query like '1st'}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12086 \textcolor{comment}{**   will match against "{}1st"{} and "{}first"{}. This method does not require}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12087 \textcolor{comment}{**   extra disk space, as no extra entries are added to the FTS index.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12088 \textcolor{comment}{**   On the other hand, it may require more CPU cycles to run MATCH queries,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12089 \textcolor{comment}{**   as separate queries of the FTS index are required for each synonym.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12090 \textcolor{comment}{**}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12091 \textcolor{comment}{**   When using methods (2) or (3), it is important that the tokenizer only}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12092 \textcolor{comment}{**   provide synonyms when tokenizing document text (method (2)) or query}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12093 \textcolor{comment}{**   text (method (3)), not both. Doing so will not cause any errors, but is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12094 \textcolor{comment}{**   inefficient.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12095 \textcolor{comment}{*/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{12096 \textcolor{keyword}{typedef} \textcolor{keyword}{struct }Fts5Tokenizer Fts5Tokenizer;}
